head.headtext: Chemical tests of bodily fluids—Blood tests—Blood-alcohol and intoxication

para.paratext: Evidence of a person's blood-alcohol level is admissible and relevant regarding intoxication. Blood alcohol evidence may be presented through the results of a blood test or breath analysis.[1]

Since the scientific basis for determining the percentage of alcohol in blood is well recognized, an expert witness may state an opinion as to the possible extent of intoxication of the individual.[2]

One of the earliest cases in Georgia to consider the blood-alcohol test was a civil action involving a collision between plaintiff's automobile and defendant's bus.[3] Although the defendant contended that the plaintiff was intoxicated at the time of the collision, the plaintiff's expert witness testified that, plaintiff's blood alcohol test results indicated that the plaintiff was not intoxicated.

In 1953, Georgia enacted a statute that created certain presumptions from the results of blood alcohol tests for the offense of driving under the influence of intoxicating liquor.[4] Then, in 1974, Georgia changed much of the prior law through enactment of the Uniform Rules of the Road, O.C.G.A. Title 40, Ch.6. The present version of O.C.G.A. § 40-6-392 provides:

Upon the trial of any civil or criminal action or proceeding arising out of acts alleged to have been committed by any person [driving while impaired], evidence of the amount of alcohol or drug in a person's blood, urine, breath, or other bodily substance at the alleged time, as determined by a chemical analysis of the person's blood, urine, breath, or other bodily substance shall be admissible.

The statute established that the procedures and equipment used for performing chemical tests on bodily fluids should meet standards established by the Georgia Bureau of Investigation Division of Forensic Sciences.[5] Additionally, the statute establishes certain factual inferences[6] that may be drawn from those test results.
A defendant's refusal to permit chemical analysis of his blood, breath, urine, or other bodily substance at the time of his arrest is admissible against him.[7]

The statute requires that arresting officer advise the defendant of his legal right to request an independent chemical test of his bodily substances.[8] The Georgia Court of Appeals considered this issue in Nelson v. State[9] and stated that the “legislature intended that this right be made known to the defendant at the time of his arrest in order that he may, if he so chooses, challenge the accuracy of the chemical test administered by the state at the only time such a challenge would be meaningful.” If he is not so advised, then the results of the test that was made would be inadmissible.[10] In Martin v. State,[11] the results of a blood test were admissible against a defendant who was properly warned as required by Nelson.

In Garrett v. Department of Public Safety,[12] the Georgia Supreme Court approved Nelson and extended it by holding that defendant's refusal to submit to a blood alcohol test was justified since he had not been informed of his right to have an independent test by someone of his own choosing.

In Hulsey v. State,[13] the Georgia Court of Appeals held that the results of defendant's breath test should have been suppressed because he was advised of his right to have independent blood or breath tests, but he was not advised of his right to urine analysis.

The state must show affirmatively that the defendant was advised of his right to an additional test. Defendant's noncompliance or nonwaiver of additional testing are affirmative defenses.[14] The state does not have to show a defendant's consent to chemical testing after receiving notice pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-6-392, but only that he did not refuse testing.[15] Also, the officer may allow the driver to choose which chemical test(s) to take.[16] Test results are admissible absent an implied consent warning if a driver voluntarily consents to a chemical test of his bodily fluids.[17] However, without the consent of an accused, warrantless, nonconsensual blood testing is not permitted unless it is reasonable based on the totality of the circumstances. “[W]hile the natural dissipation of alcohol in the blood may support a finding of exigency in a specific case, it does not do so categorically” in all cases.[18] An officer is obligated to make a reasonable effort to accommodate a defendant's request for an independent test by qualified medical personnel of his own choosing.[19]

The Court of Appeals permitted a log sheet of test results, created at the time the breath test was administered, under a business records exception to the hearsay rule where the original breath test result print-out was misplaced.[20]

In Perano v. State,[21] the Georgia Supreme Court held that police must advise a motorist “at the time of arrest, or at a time as close in proximity to the instant of arrest as the circumstances of the individual case might warrant… or the results of the state-administered test will not be admissible at trial to show that the accused was driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs.”[22] The court considered 30 minutes after the arrest a reasonable time because the suspect was having an altercation with his wife in the stopped car, thereby delaying the arresting officer's reading of his implied consent rights.

Following Perano, a number of courts expanded this “proximity” concept and rights advisement requirement to suspects not under arrest.[23] However, these cases were overruled expressly in Hough v. State.[24] In Hough, the Georgia Supreme Court analyzed Georgia's “implied consent statutes,”[25] which provide that any person who operates a motor vehicle is deemed to have given consent to a blood-alcohol test “if arrested” for any DUI offense, and held that the statutes clearly require an arrest, but do not require a “formal arrest.”[26] A person is arrested and subject to the statutory provisions at the point that his liberty to come and go as he pleases is restrained, regardless how slight the restraint.[27]

Georgia's implied consent notice requires that the defendant be given notice, which is “substantially accurate so as to permit the driver to make an informed decision about whether to consent to testing.”[28] The officer may choose which test(s) to administer and does not have to designate a specific test at the time of the implied consent notice. In Nagata v. State,[29] the Georgia Court of Appeals affirmed the trial court's denial of defendant's motion to suppress the results of his state-administered breath tests because the arresting officer may choose which tests to administer and defendant's notice that the state would test his blood, breath, urine, or other bodily substance allowed him to make an informed decision regarding his consent to such testing. The Supreme Court has held that the implied consent notice is not per se coercive on its face.[30] Likewise, the Court of Appeals has upheld the implied consent notice as it applies to drivers under 21.[31]

The United States Supreme Court held in California v. Trombetta[32] that due process does not require the state to preserve the actual breath samples in order to introduce the results of a breath-analysis test in evidence. Georgia courts follow Trombetta,[33]

Unless a proponent can properly identify the blood sample used in the test as that of the person in question and establish chain of custody,[34] the results of the test will not be admissible in evidence.[35] However, arguments regarding the chain of custody, where the evidence is admitted by the trial court, go to the weight and credit of the evidence, and resolution of conflicting or contradictory evidence goes to the trier of fact.[36]
Lattarulo v. State, 261 Ga. 124, 401 S.E.2d 516 (1991); Brannan v. State, 261 Ga. 128, 401 S.E.2d 269 (1991).

See Ladd and Gibson, Medico-Legal Aspects of the Blood Test to Determine Intoxication, 24 Iowa L. Rev. 191 (1938) and a similar article by the same authors, 29 Va. L. Rev. 749 (1943); Busch, Blood in the Courts, 18 Ala. Law. 253 (1957); Comment: 30 N.C. L. Rev. 302 (1952).
The legal blood alcohol level of a person operating a motor vehicle is.10. 2013 Ga. S.B. 136 lowered the legal blood alcohol level from.10 to.08 for individuals operating a boat.
Macon Busses v. Dashiell, 73 Ga. App. 108, 35 S.E.2d 666 (1945).
See former O.C.G.A. § 68-1625.

The 2001 amendment substituted the term “inferences” for “presumption,” which caused a problem when the language of O.C.G.A. § 40-6-392(b) was included in the court's charge in a DUI case. The United States Supreme Court has held that including a presumption in a jury charge improperly shifts the burden of proof to the defendant in a criminal case. Francis v. Franklin, 471 U.S. 307, 105 S. Ct. 1965, 85 L. Ed. 2d 344 (1985). Thus, the Georgia Court of Appeals in King v. State, 200 Ga. App. 511, 408 S.E.2d 509 (1991), reversed a DUI conviction because the trial court had included the “presumption” language of O.C.G.A. § 40-6-392(b) in its jury charge.
Nelson v. State, 135 Ga. App. 212, 217 S.E.2d 450 (1975).
See Nelson v. State, 135 Ga. App. 212, 217 S.E.2d 450 (1975).
Martin v. State, 139 Ga. App. 8, 228 S.E.2d 15 (1976).
Garrett v. Department of Public Safety, 237 Ga. 413, 228 S.E.2d 812 (1976).
See Smith v. State, 143 Ga. App. 347, 238 S.E.2d 698 (1977); Beaman v. State, 161 Ga. App. 129, 291 S.E.2d 244 (1982); Huff v. State, 144 Ga. App. 764, 242 S.E.2d 361 (1978).

In Jordan v. Ensley, 149 Ga. App. 67, 253 S.E.2d 414 (1979), aff'd, 244 Ga. 435, 260 S.E.2d 480 (1979), the court held that the same rule applied in civil cases, so the results of the test were not admissible to show intoxication. However, the results were admissible for impeachment under O.C.G.A. § 24-9-82 [§ 24-6-621 eff. Jan. 1, 2013].

Grizzle v. State, 153 Ga. App. 364, 265 S.E.2d 324 (1980), held that although the officer must advise the accused of his right to an independent test, he need not insure the performance of such a test.
Hulsey v. State, 138 Ga. App. 221, 225 S.E.2d 752 (1976).

See State v. Dull, 176 Ga. App. 152, 335 S.E.2d 605 (1985); Snelling v. State, 176 Ga. App. 192, 335 S.E.2d 475 (1985); Glicksberg v. State, 176 Ga. App. 513, 336 S.E.2d 336 (1985); Osteen v. State, 176 Ga. App. 722, 337 S.E.2d 369 (1985); Cunningham v. State, 255 Ga. 35, 334 S.E.2d 656 (1985); State v. Carter, 178 Ga. App. 677, 344 S.E.2d 499 (1986); State v. Peters, 211 Ga. App. 755, 440 S.E.2d 515 (1994).
McMullen v. State, 316 Ga. App. 684, 730 S.E.2d 151 (2012).
Missouri v. McNeely, 133 S. Ct. 1552, 185 L. Ed. 2d 696 (2013).
State v. Metzager, 303 Ga. App. 17, 692 S.E.2d 687 (2010).
Jones v. State, 345 Ga. App. 14, 812 S.E.2d 337 (2018).
See, e.g., State v. Lentsch, 252 Ga. App. 655, 658, 556 S.E.2d 248 (2001).

Hough v. State, 279 Ga. 711, 620 S.E.2d 380 (2005). In Mackey v. Montrym, 443 U.S. 1, 99 S. Ct. 2612, 61 L. Ed. 2d 321 (1979), the court held that “implied consent” statutes did not violate federal due process. Mackey was followed in Illinois v. Batchelder, 463 U.S. 1112, 103 S. Ct. 3513, 77 L. Ed. 2d 1267 (1983).

Nagata v. State, 319 Ga. App. 513, 736 S.E.2d 474 (2013). See also Jones v. State, 319 Ga. App. 520, 737 S.E.2d 318 (2013), where court upheld trial court's denial of a motion to suppress the results of a state-administered breath test when officer only referred to a blood test in his notice to defendant.
Bergstrom v. State, 347 Ga. App. 295, 819 S.E.2d 84 (2018).
California v. Trombetta, 467 U.S. 479, 104 S. Ct. 2528, 81 L. Ed. 2d 413 (1984).
The same result was reached as to vials of blood in Spivey v. State, 170 Ga. App. 196, 316 S.E.2d 822 (1984).
Hopper v. State, 175 Ga. App. 358, 333 S.E.2d 201 (1985), followed California v. Trombetta as to the federal claim and reached the same result under Georgia law.

Russell v. Pitts, 105 Ga. App. 147, 123 S.E.2d 708 (1961); Interstate Life & Acc. Ins. Co. v. Whitlock, 112 Ga. App. 212, 144 S.E.2d 532 (1965); Elliott v. Leavitt, 122 Ga. App. 622, 178 S.E.2d 268 (1970); Painter v. State, 237 Ga. 30, 226 S.E.2d 578 (1976).
The chain of custody was properly shown in Johnson v. State, 184 Ga. App. 745, 362 S.E.2d 450 (1987).

King v. State, 89 Ga. App. 626, 80 S.E.2d 493 (1954); Pittman v. State, 110 Ga. App. 625, 139 S.E.2d 507 (1964); Starks v. State, 113 Ga. App. 780, 149 S.E.2d 841 (1966); Unigard Ins. Co. v. Elmore, 137 Ga. App. 665, 224 S.E.2d 762 (1976); Pugmire Lincoln Mercury, Inc. v. Sorrells, 142 Ga. App. 444, 236 S.E.2d 113 (1977).
Holland v. State, 329 Ga. App. 103, 763 S.E.2d 894 (2014).
